image.altText: a woman wearing a suit looks sideways

items.synopsis: News headlines about the corruption watchdog's findings against Gladys Berejiklian this week left many scratching their heads and wondering why she won't face any criminal charges for her conduct.

title.children: The 'heavy punishment' Gladys Berejiklian faces despite legal charges being ruled out

image.altText: Passengers queing at airport

items.synopsis: Passengers at Sydney Airport have been hit with a second day of flight cancellations and delays due to gusty winds.

title.children: More than 30 flights cancelled at Sydney Airport on first day of school holidays

image.altText: Man runs behind flaming debris in street

items.synopsis: French police clear protesters from the iconic central Paris square of Place de la Concorde as officials refuse to rule out a state of emergency.

title.children: France deploys 45,000 police officers as violent protests erupt

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An explosion has been triggered in the Marseilles Vieux-Port, says news outlet BFMTV. It's understood there have been no injuries despite the footage of the explosion circulating on social media.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Reports of explosion at Marseille port

children.content: An explosion has been triggered in the Marseilles Vieux-Port, says news outlet BFMTV.
It's understood there have been no injuries despite the footage of the explosion circulating on social media.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The mayor of Marseille has called on the government for "immediate" dispatch of law enforcement. Benoit Payan tweeted to "strongly condemn" vandalism and looting in the city. France's interior minister says "significant" police reinforcements are arriving in the city now.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Marseille mayor asks for 'immediate' reinforcements amid looting

children.content: The mayor of Marseille has called on the government for "immediate" dispatch of law enforcement.
Benoit Payan tweeted to "strongly condemn" vandalism and looting in the city.
France's interior minister says "significant" police reinforcements are arriving in the city now.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: France's interior minister Gerald Darmanin says there have been more than 270 arrests in France. He added "significant reinforcements" were arriving in Marseille.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hundreds of arrests already as police reinforcements arrive

children.content: France's interior minister Gerald Darmanin says there have been more than 270 arrests in France.
He added "significant reinforcements" were arriving in Marseille.

image.altText: a cloud band forms over the kimberley

items.synopsis: Unseasonable rain continues to fall across Australia's north in what's meant to be the region's dry season, helping lower temperatures to near-record levels.

title.children: Why holiday-makers heading north for winter sun could be in for unpleasant surprise

image.altText: Fice young protesters sit on the ground on a street in Paris, facing police officers

items.synopsis: French police clear protesters from the iconic central Paris square of Place de la Concorde after an impromptu demonstration started amid nationwide unrest following the fatal shooting of a teenager by police.

title.children: France holds crisis meetings, Macron blames riots on people 'intoxicated' by video games

image.altText: Vladimir Putin's face is lit by warm sunlight. He wears dark sunglasses and a black jacket on black shirt

items.synopsis: As the war grinds on and the traitor Yevgeny Prigozhin is allowed to live on in exile, the question must be asked: Is Vladimir Putin losing his grip on power?

title.children: Russia's elites have a plan in case Putin is toppled. Here's how it could happen

image.altText: A woman resting her chin on her hand smiles at the camera.

items.synopsis: Millions of Australians are opting for career changes, but experts say the window may be closing to get the most out of the "Great Reshuffle". This is how mid-career professionals jumped at the chance for an occupation transformation and set themselves up for a more fulfilling work future.

title.children: Would you take a $50,000 pay cut? Why these mid-career professionals aren't looking back

image.altText: Birds fly out the front of Parliament House

items.synopsis: For years, debate has raged in the nation's capital about the need for a federal anti-corruption watchdog — one with actual teeth. Now the National Anti-Corruption Commission is here, so what will it achieve?

title.children: The Army Major General turned federal anti-corruption boss officially starts today - what's ahead of him?

image.altText: Jim Chalmers sitting in the House of Representatives. He holds his hand over his mouth.

items.synopsis: The cost-of-living crisis cannot be resolved by one institution alone and raising interest rates isn't the only way to take money out of the economy, writes David Taylor.

title.children: Interest rates needn't be as high as they are, but the government would need to act, top economist says

image.altText: Two men in suits walk down a footpath, one in front of the other. The one in front is shielding his face with a clipboard.

items.synopsis: The ex-officer has been found guilty in Lismore District Court of knowingly having sex with a child under the age of 16.

title.children: Jury finds former NSW police officer guilty of sex with minor

image.altText: A bald man looking at the camera

items.synopsis: There are concerns the reputation of Wagga Wagga in southern NSW has been tarnished by the ICAC finding that former MP Daryl Maguire engaged in serious corrupt conduct.

title.children: 'Dragged through the mud': The ICAC probe's impact on Wagga's reputation

image.altText: Two women stand back to back with their arms crossed and smile.

items.synopsis: Jack Yabsley, a former presenter of Saturday Disney and Totally Wild, describes his new TV series Gold Diggers as an anti-patriarchal, "grubby, political, silly, sexy comedy".

title.children: Former kids' TV presenter creates bawdy comedy about women on Australia's goldfields

image.altText: Allan Border smiles while wearing a tuxedo at an awards ceremony

items.synopsis: Australian cricket great Allan Border tells News Corp it will be "a miracle" if he makes it to 80 after living with Parkinson's for years.

title.children: Allan Border reveals he has Parkinson's disease

image.altText: A young woman with brown hair smiles at the camera

items.synopsis: A move to use a partner from a private PR firm to backfill as the media advisor for the Tasmanian premier is labelled "wrong" and "inappropriate" and should be "terminated forthwith", critics say.

title.children: 'Obviously wrong': PR firm partner to fill in as premier's media advisor

image.altText: Two men in bright yellow hazmat suits attend to a large yellow firefighting hose in a car park.

items.synopsis: The accusation came after Kyiv accused Russia earlier in June of planning a "terrorist" attack at the nuclear plant involving the release of radiation, which Moscow has denied.

title.children: Russians reducing personnel at Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, Ukrainian intelligence says

image.altText: Stuart Broad shrugs while holding a ball during an Ashes Test against Australia.

items.synopsis: England's ultra-attacking batting costs them dearly once again, with near misses during Australia's second innings twisting the knife into Stuart Broad in particular.

title.children: Five quick hits — Stuart Broad gets in a strop after England's batters fall in a heap again

image.altText: Pat Cummins lies on his back while completing a catch, Josh Hazlewood pumps his fist and Jonny Bairstow watches on

items.synopsis: With the match in the balance on the third morning, an incredible display of irresponsible English batting gifted Australia the ascendancy and again raised questions about the validity of the host's tactical approach.

title.children: England's absurd batting gifts Australia Ashes advantage and puts Bazball in the firing line

image.altText: An illustration of a woman reading in bed, with a knitted sweater reading "heart ABC Arts".

items.synopsis: Need a good book to snuggle up with as temperatures drop? The stars of this June’s best books include a teacher on a road trip with a corpse, a novelist grappling with her mother’s funeral, and prisoners doomed to fight to the death.

title.children: ‘Quietly devastating’, ‘beautifully told’, a ‘blistering critique’: Five must-read books

image.altText: Taylor swift in a gold body suit singing into a microphone with a male dancer behind her

items.synopsis: Like scent, musical memory is powerful. It time-travels. And so, thanks to legions of desperate Taylor Swift fans, this week I was transported back to my teenage years, where my love for Kate Bush began, writes Virginia Trioli.

title.children: When you truly love an artist like Taylor Swift, your passion remains in pristine form. I know just what it's like

image.altText: Actor Alan arkin poses with his Oscar smiling gently, wearing a suit

items.synopsis: Tributes from Hollywood flood in after the actor's sons confirmed their father's death.

title.children: Oscar winner Alan Arkin dies at 89

image.altText: Narendra Modi gestures with arms wide and palms up as he speaks into two mics at a lectern.

items.synopsis: As the next federal elections loom in India, Prime Minister Narendra Modi is pushing for a single legal code to cover matters currently governed by different sets of laws for different religious groups.

title.children: In India, marriage, divorce, adoption and inheritance laws differ for every religious group

image.altText: Fireworks light up the sky and silhouettes of people watching

items.synopsis: This year 228 tonnes of fireworks have been imported and people will detonate them with few rules and regulations — long after cracker nights were banned in every other state and territory.

title.children: Why people in the NT hold tight the right to blow things up for one wild night each year

image.altText: Ishan Jayasekara, Lasitha Bandara and Supun Pollgolla stand together, looking serious.

items.synopsis: Four men badly burned when a gas bottle exploded in Canberra nearly five years ago say they are still suffering from the pain and trauma.

title.children: 'It felt like hell': Four men burned in Canberra gas explosion say they remain physically and mentally scarred

image.altText: Passengers being evacuated from an airport after shooting.

items.synopsis: Authorities say a Tajik man who was denied entry into Moldova's main international airport fatally shot two security officers.

title.children: Traveller shoots two people dead at Moldova airport, officials say

image.altText: Michael Bond stands next to his red car at night at a charging station.

items.synopsis: While the take-up of electric vehicles has surged in recent years, EV advocates say Victoria has fallen behind New South Wales in its spending on charging stations.

title.children: Australians are embracing electric vehicles in record numbers. But the switch isn't always cheap or easy

image.altText: Mark Cavendish sprays champagne

items.synopsis: As British sprinter Mark Cavendish looks to break Eddie Merckx's record for stage wins at the Tour, Tadej Pogačar and defending champion Jonas Vingegaard resume their battle for overall honours when then race gets underway tonight.

title.children: A Tour de France great is on the cusp of history. One Aussie is in his corner — and another is hell-bent on stopping him

image.altText: Brazil's former President Jair Bolsonaro speaks with media as he arrives at the airport

items.synopsis: Brazil's Supreme Electoral Court votes to bar former president Jair Bolsonaro from public office until 2030 for his conduct during last year's fraught election.

title.children: Brazilian court bars former president Bolsonaro from office until 2030 over 'violent speech and lies'

image.altText: Commander James O'Brien pictured outside the court

items.synopsis: The coroner heard the officer had been relieved of his acting assistant commissioner duties after giving an "unfortunate interview" on ABC Radio, where he was questioned about the NT police force's response to domestic violence call-outs.

title.children: Senior NT cop 'no longer fulfilling' acting assistant commissioner role after 'unfortunate interview', DV inquest hears

image.altText: A man sitting in a vehicle wearing orange hi-vis and a white helmet

items.synopsis: Gary Henry White, 48, has admitted he married a second woman when he was still legally wed to his first wife in an extremely rare prosecution of bigamy.

title.children: 'Extremely serious in our culture': Perth man admits being married to two women

image.altText: Spacey, wearing a blue suit and pink tie, gives a closed lipped smile

items.synopsis: The trial of Kevin Spacey for a dozen allegations of sexual assault is under way in London, during which prosecutors allege the actor "delights in making others feel powerless and uncomfortable".

title.children: Kevin Spacey described as 'sexual bully' by prosecutors as allegations aired in court

image.altText: A Sydney Swans player kicks around his body towards goal during a game.

items.synopsis: Geelong claims two points off Sydney as the Swans errant kicking costs them dearly in the run to the finals.

title.children: 'None is probably what we deserve': Scott concedes Swans were the better team as Cats steal a draw

image.altText: A group of rugby league players celebrate winning a match

items.synopsis: Melbourne hosting Penrith was supposed to be the match of the round but it ended with the Panthers reaffirming their place as premiership favourites.

title.children: Penrith make powerful premiership statement with Melbourne mauling

image.altText: A Tasmanian native hen stands among green grass and fallen autumn leaves while another looks for food in the background

items.synopsis: The humble native Tasmanian hen, also known as the "turbo chook", is a familiar creature on the southern island. New research suggests it's going to stay that way even in the face of a changing climate.

title.children: Tasmania's 'turbo chooks' to continue thriving, study finds
